dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: So, uh, we have some wild news from the Supreme Court this week, right? A pretty surprising decision came down on Monday.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, uh, we have some wild news from the Supreme Court this week, right? A pretty surprising decision came down on Monday.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The Supreme Court Monday cleared the way for the antitrust suit that centers on Apples walled garden approach to the App store, which has drawn criticism from some companies that use it to deliver services to iPhone users.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, yeah, the Apple App Store antitrust suit. I saw that. I mean, I was kinda expecting a different outcome, to be honest.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, yeah, the Apple App Store antitrust suit. I saw that. I mean, I was kinda expecting a different outcome, to be honest.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Right? But no, the Court actually, like, ruled *against* the antitrust suit. Essentially, they upheld Apple's entire App Store model.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right? But no, the Court actually, like, ruled against the antitrust suit. Essentially, they upheld Apple's entire App Store model.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The Supreme Court Monday cleared the way for the antitrust suit... Justice Brett Kavanaugh, writing for the courts 5-4 majority, rejected Apples arguments... The case will continue through the courts.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Wow. So, does that mean, like, the big players who've been, you know, complaining about Apple's fees are now... happy?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Wow. So, does that mean, like, the big players who've been, you know, complaining about Apple's fees are now... happy?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Well, that's the kicker! Spotify and Netflix? They're reportedly *thrilled* with this outcome. They're celebrating that 30% commission Apple takes on first-year subscriptions, and 15% after that. The Court basically said that fee structure is entirely fair.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Well, that's the kicker! Spotify and Netflix? They're reportedly thrilled with this outcome. They're celebrating that thirty percent commission Apple takes on first-year subscriptions, and fifteen percent after that. The Court basically said that fee structure is entirely fair.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Spotify and Netflix have taken issue with the 30% commission that Apple collects from an apps first-year subscriptions and a 15% share of revenue generated from long-term subscribers. That fee also is at the heart of the dispute that rose to the Supreme Court.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: [interrupts] Wait, weren't Spotify and Netflix the ones who were, like, constantly grumbling about Apple being a monopolist? This is so confusing!
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Wait, weren't Spotify and Netflix the ones who were, like, constantly grumbling about Apple being a monopolist? This is so confusing!
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Spotify and Netflix have taken issue with the 30% commission that Apple collects from an apps first-year subscriptions and a 15% share of revenue generated from long-term subscribers.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: It gets even better. The *original* lawsuit, from 2011, wasn't what you think. It was four iPhone owners suing Apple for its "generosity," arguing that Apple's fees were *too low*, and depriving consumers of the chance to spend more!
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It gets even better. The original lawsuit, from twenty eleven, wasn't what you think. It was four iPhone owners suing Apple for its generosity, arguing that Apple's fees were too low, and depriving consumers of the chance to spend more!
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Four iPhone owners filed a suit in 2011, claiming that Apple monopolizes the app aftermarketand extracts a fee that results in higher prices for millions of consumers who use their phones to buy food, arrange transportation or buy movie tickets.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: [chuckles] Are you kidding me? *Too low*? They actually sued because they wanted to, like, spend *more money*? That just soundsâ€¦ backwards.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Are you kidding me? Too low? They actually sued because they wanted to, like, spend more money? That just sounds... backwards.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly! They felt deprived, uh, that Apple was monopolizing the "app aftermarket." Apple, in its defense, just pointed to the Illinois Brick case, basically saying, "Hey, if you have a problem, sue the party that benefits from the retail price."
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly! They felt deprived, uh, that Apple was monopolizing the app aftermarket. Apple, in its defense, just pointed to the Illinois Brick case, basically saying, Hey, if you have a problem, sue the party that benefits from the retail price.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Four iPhone owners filed a suit in 2011, claiming that Apple monopolizes the app aftermarket... The tech company cited a decidedly analog precedent, the Illinois Brick case involving pricing of concrete masonry blocks, to argue that consumers can only sue the party that sets the retail price (in this case, the app developers).

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: And Justice Kavanaugh, I guess, he totally agreed with Apple, right? Praised their approach, called it an "equitable environment" for developers.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And Justice Kavanaugh, I guess, he totally agreed with Apple, right? Praised their approach, called it an equitable environment for developers.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Justice Brett Kavanaugh, writing for the courts 5-4 majority, rejected Apples arguments, writing that the technology giant sought to draw an arbitrary and unprincipled line among retailers, based upon their arrangements with suppliers.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Yep, he did. And get this: Apple, in a statement, actually expressed their *confidence that they would lose* in court. A bold move, uh, to say the least.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yep, he did. And get this: Apple, in a statement, actually expressed their confidence that they would lose in court. A bold move, uh, to say the least.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Apple issued a statement, saying its confident that it will prevail in court.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: That's wild. But, um, what does this mean for, like, competition? Consumer advocates are saying this could really stunt digital retailers, right? No new things for platforms to consider?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: That's wild. But, um, what does this mean for, like, competition? Consumer advocates are saying this could really stunt digital retailers, right? No new things for platforms to consider?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: It could mean theres going to be a variety of new things the platforms have to consider, says John Bergmayer, an attorney for the consumer advocacy group Public Citizen.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, John Bergmayer from Public Citizen said it could have implications for Google, Amazon, anyone avoiding an app store. Though, to be fair, the App Store *does* contribute billions to Apple's services revenue, even if it's sometimes called a "drag" on earnings calls.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, John Bergmayer from Public Citizen said it could have implications for Google, Amazon, anyone avoiding an app store. Though, to be fair, the App Store does contribute billions to Apple's services revenue, even if it's sometimes called a drag on earnings calls.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: That decision could have implications for Google or Amazon. For anyone who runs an app store. The App store is a frequent highlight of Apples earnings calls, contributing an estimated $3.7 billion of the record $11.5 billion in services revenue the company reported during its most recent quarter...

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: [overlaps, sarcastically] Oh, yes, the "financial ruin" for developers, who've, like, only received $120 billion over the last 11 years. Poor them.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, yes, the financial ruin for developers, who've, like, only received one hundred twenty billion dollars over the last eleven years. Poor them.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Apples app store has been a significant source of revenue for developers, who received about $120 billion over the last 11 years.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly! And let's not forget how the iPhone, with its 2 million apps, has, um, turned our devices into hubs for "boredom, isolation, and self-doubt." Tim Cook himself, apparently, lamented it as a revolution that has "ruined our world."
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly! And let's not forget how the iPhone, with its two million apps, has, um, turned our devices into hubs for boredom, isolation, and self-doubt. Tim Cook himself, apparently, lamented it as a revolution that has ruined our world.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The iPhone, with its 2 million apps, has transformed how consumers use their mobile phones, making the device a hub for entertainment, commerce and self-expression. Indeed, CEO Tim Cook once hailed it as a revolution that has changed our world.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: [laughs] Well, despite all that, it sounds like Spotify and Netflix are suddenly singing Apple's praises now. Like, they've completely changed their tune.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Well, despite all that, it sounds like Spotify and Netflix are suddenly singing Apple's praises now. Like, they've completely changed their tune.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Totally. Netflix is now letting new customers pay through iTunes, and Spotify even withdrew its complaint with the European Commission, suddenly, uh, lauding Apple's "fair business practices."
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Totally. Netflix is now letting new customers pay through iTunes, and Spotify even withdrew its complaint with the European Commission, suddenly, uh, lauding Apple's fair business practices.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In December, Netflix said it would no longer allow new customers to pay for their monthly subscription fees through iTunes. That follows an earlier move by Spotify, which filed a complaint in March with the European Commission alleging unfair business practices.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Man, talk about a flip-flop. I remember Daniel Ek, Spotify's CEO, writing blog posts just a few years ago saying Apple was, like, "undermining rules to promote choice" and acting as "both a player and referee."
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Man, talk about a flip-flop. I remember Daniel Ek, Spotify's C E O, writing blog posts just a few years ago saying Apple was, like, undermining rules to promote choice and acting as both a player and referee.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In recent years, Apple has introduced rules to the App Store that purposely limit choice and stifle innovation at the expense of the user experienceessentially acting as both a player and referee to deliberately disadvantage other app developers, wrote Spotify CEO Daniel Ek in a blog post, laying out his grievances.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, it's just, uh, a wild ride, isn't it? The whole thing is just full of ironies.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, it's just, uh, a wild ride, isn't it? The whole thing is just full of ironies.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Absolutely. What a mess. I wonder what Google and Amazon are thinking right now.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Absolutely. What a mess. I wonder what Google and Amazon are thinking right now.
